37573aee6e66c967ef7bf85542d2b3aa.title: How Corona Became the ‘Fast & Furious’ Beer of Choice

1a949947eb6cb714cc20d7e091d4daa9.title: How Corona Became the ‘Fast & Furious’ Beer of Choice

paragraphs.name: 18e7
paragraphs.text: And yet, according to everyone we spoke to, Corona doesn’t even pay to be in the movies. “On all the stuff I’ve ever done, I don’t believe there ever was [a deal with Corona],” says Morgan. “The truth is we write it in there. We talk about it. It’s what it’s going to be, and not for any business reasons. It’s part of Dom’s character. It just is.”

content.subtitle: All the snobs talking about how it sucks need to get a life. Its beer not wine

56af7caf4f74.title: Corona is traditionally a Mexican drink not a Asian or a black drink.

virtuals.subtitle: All the snobs talking about how it sucks need to get a life. Its beer not wine

paragraphs.text: Corona is traditionally a Mexican drink not a Asian or a black drink. Latinos made it popular, if you don’t believe me go to any Mexican party. You’ll find it there. You might find it at other parties, but its 100% going to be at Mexican parties.

d57935c50592.title: You know how the original Fast and Furious is basically a Point Break ripoff?

paragraphs.name: 78c9
paragraphs.text: You know how the original Fast and Furious is basically a Point Break ripoff? Well, it’s worth noting that in one scene in Point Break when Johnny Utah and Angelo are at the office late trying to figure out who the Ex-Presidents are, they’re drinking… Corona.
